[start of motion plan]
The task is to break the wrist while grasping the wrist.

Mapping World Motion to Wrist Motion:
The provided workspace image confirms a robot arm with a gripper positioned near the edge of a wooden table surface in a laboratory setting. The robot wrist frame is annotated with axes: red (+X) pointing roughly rightward relative to the robot base, green (+Y) pointing roughly toward the background (into the scene), and blue (+Z) pointing roughly upward vertically. The wrist is grasping a small object, presumably the wrist of some device needing to be broken or detached. The workspace is clear except for some monitors, cables, and equipment on tables around the robot.

The labeled wrist axes correspond to the world as such: 
- Wrist X-axis (red, +X) points roughly right in the world frame (matching world +X).
- Wrist Y-axis (green, +Y) points roughly forward into the workspace (matching world +Z or depth).
- Wrist Z-axis (blue, +Z) points roughly upward vertical in the world (matching world +Y).

The blue axis represents wrist Z-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to vertical upward and downward motion in the world frame. Positive wrist Z is upward vertical motion; negative wrist Z is downward.

Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Z-axis, the object must move downward (negative Z) to break the wrist with controlled force applying pressure down.

The red axis represents wrist X-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to right-left horizontal motion in the world frame. Positive wrist X is motion rightward, negative is motion leftward.

Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist X-axis, the object must move slightly to the right (positive X) to help disengage or apply lateral force while breaking the wrist.

The green axis represents wrist Y-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to forward-backward motion into and out of the scene in the world frame. Positive wrist Y is forward into the workspace, negative wrist Y is backward.

Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Y-axis, the object must move slightly forward (positive Y) to position or push for breaking.

To accomplish the task in the wrist frame, the object must be moved downwards (negative Z) with coordinated small rightward (positive X) and forward (positive Y) displacements to apply combined force and torque that disrupts the wrist joint and breaks it.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis:  To complete the task, the robot must exert positive force along the X-axis with magnitude 15 N on the object in the image to induce lateral stress while maintaining grip.
Linear Y-axis:  To complete the task, the robot must exert positive force along the Y-axis with magnitude 10 N on the object in the image to push forward and create dislocating force.
Linear Z-axis:  To complete the task, the robot must exert negative force along the Z-axis with magnitude 30 N on the object in the image to press downward and initiate breaking stress.

Angular X-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert clockwise torque about the X-axis with magnitude 2 N-m on the object in the image to twist the wrist joint.
Angular Y-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert counterclockwise torque about the Y-axis with magnitude 3 N-m on the object in the image to apply bending moment aiding breakage.
Angular Z-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert clockwise torque about the Z-axis with magnitude 1 N-m on the object in the image to stabilize the break motion and prevent unwanted rotation.

Grasping force:  The object is presumably plastic or metal with moderate friction; estimated wrist mass is ~0.5 kg. To prevent slippage while exerting up to 30 N downward force combined with lateral forces, the grasping force should be robust, roughly in the 40 to 60 N range to ensure firm grip without damage.

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "Small wrist component made of rigid plastic/metal, approx 0.5 kg mass, moderate friction coefficient ~0.5 against gripper pads."
# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Move object downward (negative Z) 0.05m while simultaneously moving slightly rightward (positive X) 0.01m and forward (positive Y) 0.02m to apply combined forces and torques to break the wrist joint."
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of motion across the wrist axes [x, y ,z]. 
wrist_motion_vector = [0.01, 0.02, -0.05]
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [15, 10, -30, -2, 3, -1]
# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 50
# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 5.0
```

[end of motion plan]
message:
Given the user instruction and an image of the robot workspace, generate a structured physical plan for a robot end-effector interacting with the environment.
The task is to break the wrist while grasping the wrist.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.

Use physical reasoning to complete the following plan in a structured format. Carefully map the required motion in the world to the required motion, forces, and torques at the wrist.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
